utterances: Well, Tennessee is a state that is generally sort of swing but has been trending or leaning Republican over the last 15 years or so.
George Bush won here both in 2004 and 2000 by comfy margins, as you've noted.

It's a state that right in the heart of the Bible Belt, it's a place where a lot of the voters I speak to bring up their sort of moral values and the idea of sort of a moral candidate, the idea that candidates should be pro-gun, pro-life, anti-gay marriage, and that's one of the reasons why this race is so close.
On some of the hot button issues Harold Ford, Jr. has stances that are difficult for a Republican to pin down as liberal.
Harold Ford is a U.S.
congressman, has been for the last 10 years; and he has got votes marking him being in support of the Patriot Act, for going to war in Iraq, for supporting a ban in gay marriage.

So you have the situation here where the Democrat is moderate enough, has enough experience on the campaign trail to really mount a very strong campaign against a very strong Republican candidate who we all expected to have an easier time of it.
And finally, in one of the analyses I saw, Harold Ford is really relying on urban areas to pump up the black vote and push him over the victory line.
Do you think that that is how things will play out if he wins?
And if he doesn't, what will be - you know, if Corker wins, then what will be his cause of victory?
Well, the fact of the matter is there is just 16 percent of the vote in Tennessee is made up of black voters.
And Harold may come from Memphis, but Memphis is not enough to win this campaign.
There are a lot of rural counties where he has to make inroads; there are a lot of independent-leaning counties that are in the suburban areas around a city like, say, Nashville.
This is where both candidates have been making so many appearances because these are the counties where someone who wants to win statewide has to make serious inroads.

I think that there has been a little bit of conversation of late about whether there are some white voters in the polls who say they're going to vote for a Democrat but maybe when they get to the polls are going to change their mind because of Harold Ford's race.
This is nicknamed the Bradley effect after a 1989 L.A.
mayor who was looking good in the polls until the last minute when he lost by, you know, just, I think, 1 percent.
I think his campaign shouldn't be completely characterized by that; I don't think that's what he would want.
And I think he has done very well in his approach.
But it's going to be clear that when this race is over, win or lose, there's going to be a lot of conversation about how race played into the final vote.
Audie, thank you so much.
Thank you.
That was NPR's Audie Cornish.
: That was a huge get.
I sent him an email and just basically told him that he was my hero and that we loved him and that we were doing this thing.
And I made it sound as attractive as possible.
You know, there's going to be delicious foods.
There's going to be, you know, the greatest comedians in the world there.
And it wouldn't be complete without him because he has definitely written some of the funniest songs in the history of comedy.
And he responded with a positive.
He was like, yeah, let's do this, to my shock.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""ALWAYS LOOK ON THE BRIGHT SIDE OF LIFE"")
The power of Jack's emails cannot be underestimated.
: I do have a very seductive power with my emails.
I can get anyone to do almost anything.
Maybe you can write an email for us.
We can get President Obama on the show.
We could use you as a - you could be a great booker, Jack Black.
You're wasting it on rock and comedy.
: You really want to get Barack - you want to get Barack Obama on the - has that been something you've been trying to do for a long time?
Can you do that for us?
: I can get that done.
Yeah, Barry, he's an old pal.
What you do, though, I mean, this is - like I said, this is an insane lineup.
You...
It's a veritable who's who.
How much have you guys - I mean, is it you guys working the phones, or how did you pull it together?
I wasn't joking about the emails.
: We emailed everyone.
And basically, the trick is you tell everyone everyone else is already in.
It's a dirty trick.
And then they say: Oh, well, if they're doing it, I want to do it too.
(LAUGHTER)
: I don't know if that's entirely kosher, but you do what you got to do.
So you're playing competitive comics off of each other and - yeah.
Hey, well you're making it sound worse than it might be.
So this is a comedy and music festival.
And I believe you, gentlemen, have your guitars with you.
What?
Yeah.
Do we happen to have our guitars?
Happen to.
: You want a taste?
But this is a song we're going to play for you now.
It's kind of a departure from some of our other work.
It's ""The Ballad of Hollywood Jack and the Rage Kage.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE BALLAD OF HOLLYWOOD JACK AND THE RAGE KAGE"")
That's Jack Black and Kyle Gass.
They are Tenacious D, and they've organized an all-star comedy festival for next weekend in Santa Monica, California.
It's called Festival Supreme.
You can hear the full version of this performance without me talking over Kyle's lovely recorder solo at nprmusic.org.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE BALLAD OF HOLLYWOOD JACK AND THE RAGE KAGE"")
And for Sunday, that's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Arun Rath.
Check out our weekly podcast.
Search for WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED on iTunes.
You can follow us on Twitter @nprwatc.
Also, check out the NPR app.
We're back again next weekend.
Until then, thanks for listening and have a great week.
It's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Arun Rath.
In January 2011, David Kato, a gay rights activist in Uganda, was bludgeoned to death.
A few months earlier, his name and photograph, along with that of 100 others, had been published in a tabloid newspaper.
The article called for their execution as homosexuals.
A preacher at his funeral made remarks calling homosexuality a curse and appealing to others to repent.
At David Kato's graveside, Christopher Senyonjo, an excommunicated Anglican bishop, gave what he calls a proper farewell.
Really, don't feel discouraged.
God created you.
God is on your side.
So may God give rest to our brother.

Christopher Senyonjo is one the people featured in a new documentary ""God Loves Uganda."" Director Roger Ross Williams traces the origins of Uganda's anti-homosexuality bill, which would criminalize same-sex relations to the American evangelical movement in Uganda.
The film follows one of those groups from the International House of Prayer or IHOP.
IHOP itself is a church that has a $30 million a year operating budget and 1,000 full-time employees.
And they are a missions base.
They have a university, and their goal is to train missionaries to fulfill the great commission - to go out and to wean souls.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOCUMENTARY, ""GOLD LOVES UGANDA"")
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: God, we believe that the name the Pearl of Africa is not just a name but it is a prophetic declaration over that nation, that it is a pearl in your...
Uganda is unique in that it's been the focus of fundamentalist evangelicals from America for a long time.
Uganda has the youngest population on the planet, with the median age of just above the age of 15.

You know, America evangelicals have done a lot of great work, but it's a certain type of fundamentalist evangelical ideology that came in there and basically instilled in a lot of the young people in Uganda this message that biblical law is above any other law.
Could you talk about how - you portray in the film - how biblical beliefs become intertwined with political beliefs leading to the creation of this anti-homosexuality bill.
I think that the young missionaries in the film are really innocent and well-meaning.
They are just the foot soldiers, as I like to call them.
But I think there is the leaders.
They believe that Uganda, they have an advantage.
And everyone I've talked to in my film has said, you know, look, America's lost.
As marriage equality has passed, America is lost to them, but they are winning the war in Uganda.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOCUMENTARY, ""GOD LOVES UGANDA"")
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #2: God has what I would like to call an army of young people, only because I like that word as - it's an intense word.
But they're not a military.
Or I don't want to make that distinct - they don't have guns.
They have Bibles.
